Multi-variant testing

Challenges
Organisations do not know whether their models are adding value or which ones they should use. How can they move from gut instinct or HIPPO opinions?

Typical scenarios are:

  • My teams are building lots of models. How do I know if they are making a difference to my business goals?
  • My data science team has built a number of models for the same purpose. Which model should I use?

Recommendation:
Use multi-variant testing to run multiple models at the same time and evaluate how they affect your business metrics.

AB testing combines the common-sense approach of trying out different variations at the same time, with statistical analysis to run experiments and measure the effect on business outcomes. There are powerful tools to support this which help set up the experiments as well as collecting the measurements. In many cases it is possible to run multiple models at the same time, and to move your business operations to the 'winning' model during the experiment - gaining business benefit whilst the experiment is still in flight.

Often the end result (increase revenue, reduction in fraud etc.) is too difficult/takes too long to evaluate to be of use experimentally. So identify an intermediate metric which is correlated with the required end result.

???

Examples
John Lewis Recommendations, John Lewis Search, Plusgrade

Services catalogue

Challenges
As organisations scale they struggle to understand which teams are accountable for which services, so resolving any type of delivery challenge at scale becomes extremely difficult and time consuming.

Typical scenarios are:

  • How many teams you have, and how many services you have
  • Which teams own which services
  • Which teams have the most frequent deployments
  • Which teams have had the most recent production incidents
  • How long does it take to put a new service into production

You have multiple, distinct spreadsheets for this data, from your PMO, your architects, and your delivery teams. The spreadsheets are maintained part-time, and constantly inaccurate.

Collaborative ideation

Challenges
It's well known that “there is no shortage of ideas” and we all have a tendency to fall in love with our own ideas quickly. Deciding which idea to invest in and develop can be a difficult step and we see organisation dealing with these scenarios.

  • I know what I think the solution is already, but want buy in / budget from across my organisation and key stakeholders.
  • Our key stakeholder has a solution in mind, but I want to base our thinking on our users and use insight to uncover new opportunities and ideas.
  • We have a technical opportunity, but we're not sure what to use it for or how we can leverage this functionality to help our users.

Recommendation:
Seek diversity in your thinking, go wide and create an environment for collaborative, divergent thinking.

By this we mean thinking beyond what you already came up with; inviting fresh perspectives and exploring the novel and 'what if'. This requires both an investment of time and an open mind. We would recommend design sprints as an efficient and valuable way to generate ideas in a collaborative way, at pace, and encourage people to build on each others' ideas in a non competitive way.

This method is underpinned by user research and insights; competitor analysis and clear business goals, leading the group to focus on the most important and valuable problems to solve. Design sprints involve intensive, highly facilitated sessions with a blend of participants including key stakeholders, all focussed on problem solving. This results in early buy in for the ideas taken forward, due to the collaborative nature of the process; and a deeper understanding of what we want to achieve.

This also provides an opportunity to think about how your ideas fit with your values, this could be related to social responsibility and sustainability or thinking about the impact ideas might have on other workers within the organisations, or how you will use customer data ethically and transparently to achieve this. Taking a moment to carefully evaluate will protect you from unexpected consequences later on.

Embedding and valuing creative processes like design sprints can set the stage for how to do collaborative problem solving across the business, creating a culture where everyone can have ideas and contribute to ongoing innovation.

Examples
The Very Group, SAP, DWP

Agile as a toolkit

Challenges
You want to accelerate the delivery of value-adding features to your customers. You're spending lots of time and money on establishing a centralised delivery process. You might see:

Team members taking spending a lot of time Scrum certification and/or SAFe training Teams are forced to adhere to a particular methodology, even if it slows them down. We've heard people say before 'don't take on any more work, we have to close off the story points for this week' Teams burning a lot of time in meetings, planning for Scrum sprints and/or SAFe program increments

You don't see any reduction in the lead time to customer value. You don't know if all this investment is going to translate into better delivery. Recommendation Use agile as a toolkit within your organisation. Use the best tools from different methodologies. Apply them to your unique situation, to deliver more efficiently and in-line with your teams' preferred ways of working.

We see organisations say “we do Scrum here”, or “we do SAFe here”. Avoid dogmatic over investment in these methodologies, as it restricts the natural evolution of team ways of working. Focus on creating feedback loops, where teams reflect on their current ways of working, and then make incremental changes to improve their ways of working in future iterations. It's an experimental process. Some changes will succeed, others will not. Over time, these improvements will help teams to adapt their ways of working to more efficient delivery.

Foster a broad knowledge of agile practices across your organisation, so different tools can be applied by different teams. This includes basic practices such as daily standups, retrospectives, and stakeholder showcases, as well as more advanced techniques such as inceptions and pair-programming. Encourage teams to continuously inspect their methodology, and evaluate its effectiveness.

References

  • The productive teams by  Rajesh Thiagarajan
  • Introducing agile by Jon Ayre
  • 7 common barriers to agile adoption by ?
  • Flow is king in agile product delivery by Juan Ramón Sánchez Velar

Internal Examples

  • Greensill - Kanban teams being asked to move to Scrum and slowing down
  • HMRC CDS - days spent on PI planning, hard dependencies between teams, whole programme having to move in lockstep.

Digital platform

Challenges
As we are scaling our costs are increasing and we are going slower. Every team is solving the same problem in different ways which means they aren’t able to focus on delivering valuable features.

We have a lot of different delivery teams building and running services, but they are all working in different technologies. 

  • Lack of consistency in environments
  • Every team or service using a different technology
  • Every team solves same problem in different ways
  • Increased time in decision making 
  • Hard to hire for lots of different technology skill sets
  • Difficult to move people between different teams as each team works differently
  • Technology governance is manual and takes a long time due to a large technology surface area

Recommendation
Build an internal Platform as a Service (PaaS) composed of people, processes, and tools that enables teams to rapidly develop, iterate, and operate digital services at scale.

A Digital Platform is a set of low-friction, hardened interfaces that comprise user journeys for Digital Service teams (e.g. build a service, deploy a service, or service alerts). Those paved user journeys are fully automated and encompass the learned best practices specific to your organisation.

Each platform capability is delivered in small increments, and adjustments are made based on user feedback. Over time, as each platform capability becomes more opinionated, the Paved Road becomes wider and longer. Enabling constraints are used to encourage frequent production deployments and high standards of reliability for long-lived Digital Services.

Digital Platform eliminates common failure modes, by automating repetitive tasks and offering it as service to teams. It encourages the adoption of Continuous Delivery and Operability practices, such as constant monitoring of live traffic, and steers away from pitfalls such as End-To-End Testing. It challenges Digital Service teams to rethink how they approach particular problems, and contribute enhancements and features back into the Paved Road experience.

References

  • What is a digital platform?

  • Digital Platform Playbook

  • Paved Road

Examples

  • HMRC
  • NI
  • JL
  • Covea
  • BCG

Experimentation

Challenges
Responding to exponential change is one of the biggest challenges facing organisations today. In a world of possibilities, knowing what to go after is less clear than ever and organisations need to experiment more to find the things that will work, this includes:

  • Moving away from making gut feel decisions about the products we create and start using data and insight to inform our thinking. 
  • Figuring out which ideas are most viable and feasible to deliver to meet our business goals, whilst removing some of the risk.
  • Getting feedback early and iterating, so we can ensure our investment is worth continuing or stop if it’s unlikely to work for users or us. 

Recommendation:
Create a culture of test and learn within your organisation, and embrace experimentation as a part of problem solving. You want to design the quickest, simplest and least expensive experiment you can, to learn what you need to know.

By starting with assumptions and insights from research, you can create a set of hypotheses to test. How you choose to test and experiment will depend on what stage your product or service is at. The critical part is being able to measure and gather evidence to prove or disprove your thinking. 

At Alpha or early concept stage of a product you can create prototypes to test. By their very nature they are imperfect and throw away, enabling you to gather the feedback without a huge investment, and users are often happy to critique something less polished. These can be used to gather qualitative feedback to steer the direction of any iteration and next steps. You might test a number of different prototypes to see which performs best. This is useful for testing concepts early to see what resonates, and what really doesn’t. Being willing to drop an idea at this stage is key.

In Beta or product development, prototypes can become higher fidelity and more refined, getting you closer to your target experience. User research at this stage will involve usability testing and focus on getting the detail right, be that content, interaction or functionality. There may be several rounds of iteration. A proof of concept or tech spike could be a better way to test a hypothesis, especially where you want to prove feasibility and understand constraints..

Alongside developing new products or services, you’ll be considering new ideas for existing products. This could be refinements and improvements to an established experience. Start with data, understand the pain points for the user and the performance data for the product (registration, conversion, completion, time spent, drop out rate etc). If the data is not available or accessible, go back a step and fix that before progressing. There are no experiments without data. On live products consider A/B testing to compare and contrast results, or try Multi-variant testing. Both of these options will give you quantitative data to base your decisions on. 

Examples:
DWP, Pret, HMRC,

Cross team forums

None of the teams are learning from each other and the same class of problem is getting solved in multiple ways. For example:

  • Teams onboarding and managing knowledge in different ways
  • Teams sharing progress and managing dependencies in different ways
  • Teams taking a different approach to solving deployment challenges

This is more likely to happen as an organisation scales.

Recommendation
Set up open by default forums that are cross functional, structured e.g. product manager + DL + TL from all teams meet up once a month to share current business problems they face

Set up open by default forums/tools, sessions must be well-run to keep people on the topic/area and avoid becoming overly specialised talking shops.

(Erin) Keep an open mind to allowing organic impulses to share and be curious to take hold and thrive in ways that nurture great ideas. Offer tools that can ensure as many types of interactions can work (remote for example). Regularly check the frequency is appropriate and topics are relevant. Change it up when things get stale. This is much more than sharing what's learned from operational incidents. If a 'front door' way in is preferred, find ways for it to allow for evolving discussions.

Pitfalls:
avoid becoming general talking shops - keep it focused on a topic/theme

What not to do - talking shop for a particular specialty. Then you just limit yourself to ivory towers of leaders, because you can’t fit everyone into a meeting room. It feels like a chore

  • Tech Council of tech leads
  • Steering group of managers
  • Engineering Group of tech leads and architects
  • Principal Developer of tech leads

Self Service Tools

Challenges
You want to accelerate the delivery of value-adding features to your customers. You're spending lots of time and money on establishing a centralised delivery process. You might see:

Team members taking spending a lot of time Scrum certification and/or SAFe training Teams are forced to adhere to a particular methodology, even if it slows them down. We've heard people say before 'don't take on any more work, we have to close off the story points for this week' Teams burning a lot of time in meetings, planning for Scrum sprints and/or SAFe program increments

You don't see any reduction in the lead time to customer value. You don't know if all this investment is going to translate into better delivery. Recommendation Use agile as a toolkit within your organisation. Use the best tools from different methodologies. Apply them to your unique situation, to deliver more efficiently and in-line with your teams' preferred ways of working.

We see organisations say “we do Scrum here”, or “we do SAFe here”. Avoid dogmatic over investment in these methodologies, as it restricts the natural evolution of team ways of working. Focus on creating feedback loops, where teams reflect on their current ways of working, and then make incremental changes to improve their ways of working in future iterations. It's an experimental process. Some changes will succeed, others will not. Over time, these improvements will help teams to adapt their ways of working to more efficient delivery.

Foster a broad knowledge of agile practices across your organisation, so different tools can be applied by different teams. This includes basic practices such as daily standups, retrospectives, and stakeholder showcases, as well as more advanced techniques such as inceptions and pair-programming. Encourage teams to continuously inspect their methodology, and evaluate its effectiveness.
